etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in Henry Watts (1815–1884), chemist. From nitro- + -form, after German Nitroform (L. Schischkoff 1857)

definitions: An explosive white crystalline compound, CH(NO₂)₃, which is a derivative of methane having three nitro groups attached to the carbon atom; trinitromethane.

notes.text: "nitroform anion" noun the corresponding anion, C(NO₂)₃ −.

etymologies: 1950s; earliest use found in The Official Gazette. From nitro- + -form

definitions: A preparation of urea-formaldehyde used as a slow-release nitrogenous fertilizer.

notes.text: A trademark in the United States.
